lines.text: If you don't smoke until you're 21, I'll give you a special no-smoking present. Say goodbye to Rover, he's heartbroken.
Goodbye, Dog.
Don't eat too much, don't stay out too late, don't go to suspicious places to play cards, and stay away from girls. But most of all, Bernard, try to be happy.
[A repeated expression of his]
Whammo!
[Raef recites a poem of his]
Oh, don't you think it's very odd, That we should kneel and pray to god, When by all accounts, we might, Send our problems up by kite!
Last week I was 19. Today I'm 42. If I had an eggshell for every day I'd spent alone, I'd have a lot of eggshells.
[I.H. notices his wife sobbing over an antique bible]
Margery, your lint is settling on the Guttenberg Bible.
Aw, to hell with you're Guttenberg Bible. I hate your Guttenberg Bible!
[Barbara takes a cigarette out of Bernard's mouth]
You like those coffin nails too much. Better watch out. Better not cough.
[first lines]
You absolutely must not use the book elevator, Bernard.
Who is she?
It's illegal, it's dangerous and it'll only get you to trouble.
When you call your father 'dad' are you really thinking 'daddy'?
But Amy you were so ugly... Then.
You're perfect.
Me?
Absolutely hunky dory perfect. You're just what I need in my life.
Double trouble. Specially when it's your father and he has eyes everywhere.
I wanted you to know that I run a respectable apartment building.
Well, I run a respectable son.
What's wrong with me?
Nothing that a firing squad couldn't fix it.
Take off your jacket. Relax.
[long pause]
Would you like a drink? Coffee?
Coffee? A drink. Maybe better coffee. I mean, a drink of coffee.
I want a glass of milk.
I want a glass of milk.
You see? See how easy, sunshine?
Can you hear me, dad?
I'll see you in my office right now, big boy.
Well, gosh, I'm lonely and young. I'm always lonely even when I'm with people. Specially when I'm with people.

[about Bernard's father making a pass at her]
It was terrible.
My poor mother.
Poor me!
You took me too literally, Bernard. I'm a poet.
What's her name?
Darling. Barbara Darling. C'mon Bernard. A.P. is waiting for you.
A.P.? Who is A.P.?
Another Problem.

[Shocked, upon seeing an old painting that shows some nudity]
Oh, that filthy thing! Ohh!
Oh, yes. One of the finest examples of incunabula in the collection. It's very rare.

[Indignantly]
I'll thank you to keep your incunabula to yourself!

[Referring to Barbara's job as a go-go dancer]
Why do you have to work there? Everybody looks up your dress. Don't you feel guilty?

Look, Bernie baby, I haven't known you too long, but it seems to me that you're getting to be a regular noodge. Remember when you wrote that sweet letter to me? I thought you'd be a person that would be FUN to be with.

[Suggesting the family get away together and go to Cape Cod]
You love Cape Cod. We'll go swimming every day...

[Pushing her away]
I HATE Cape Cod! I don't want to go anywhere WITH you, I want to get AWAY from you... I'll take "Dog".
Well, Rover is gone forever. Someone stole him!
DOG! I could have named him Rover, or Spot, or Fido or anything, but I didn't! I named him DOG!

[as he unlocks and opens Bernard's jail cell]
Out you go.
Why?
You're out in custody. Your bail's been paid.

[after a thoughtful pause]
I've been in the custody of my parents for almost twenty years now. And they've taught me nothing but self-doubt, frustration, and perpetual guilt. I'm going to be in my own custody from now on. I won't go!
A nice-lookin' girl paid it.
I'll go!
[Gets up and walks out]
I have something for you.
What is it?
I found this place where they sell five-cent pretzels.
